sentences.english: Now another story.

sentences.original: êsa mînah sipwêhtêpayiw êh-pâyakot, êh-nêpêwimikot oskinîkiskwêwah, ê-wîh-kakwê-isîhkawât, osâm tâpwê wiyah êkâ êhtakohk k-ôcikihkwêyan, kah-nôcîhkawin, êh-itikot.
sentences.text: êsa mîna sipwêhtêpayiw ê-pêyakot ê-nêpêwimikot oskinîkiskwêwa ê-wî-kakwê-isîhkawât ê-itikot
sentences.english: Another young man went off alone, because a young woman had taunted him to shame when he paid court to her, saying to him, “Truly, if it were not that you are pock-marked on your face, you might woo me with success.”
At that he went off weeping, and wept off alone all the time.
Then presently he found some people.
“Why are you weeping like this?”
“Because a woman has taunted me to shame, saying to me, 'Truly, if it were not that you are pock-marked in your face, you might woo me.'”
“Why, grandchild, let me at any rate see what I can do for this.”
He built a sweat-lodge.

sentences.original: êkwah tihkisam pimiy, wâkayôsi-pimiy; wiyâkanihk astâw.
sentences.text: êkwa tihkisam pimiy wâkayôsi-pimiy wiyâkanihk astâw
sentences.english: Then he melted some fat, bear's-grease; he put it in a bowl.
Then he tied up some herbs.
“Come, now let us take a sweat-bath!” he told him.
Then the youth took off his clothes.

sentences.original: pîhtokêwak êkwah matotisânihk, pmiy mina ôma, masko-pimiy.
sentences.text: pîhtokêwak êkwa matotisânihk pimiy mîna ôma masko-pimiy
sentences.english: Then they entered the sweat-lodge, with that fat, that bear's-grease.
Their companions covered their sweatlodge for them.

sentences.original: êkwah êkos ê-sîkahasiniyêt kisêyiniw, êh-pôh-pôtâtât oskinîkiwah, piyis namoya t-êhtakoniyiw omah k-ôcikisiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa êkosi ê-sîkahasiniyêt kisêyiniw ê-pôh-pôtâtât oskinîkiwa piyis namôya ta-ihtakoniyiw ôma kâ-ocikisiyit
sentences.english: Thereupon, when the old man poured the fat on the stone, and kept blowing on the youth, at last the pock-marks on his face began to disappear.

sentences.original: piyis êh-mêstinahk pimiy ômah, mîna kîhtwâm pîhtokatâwân.
sentences.text: piyis ê-mêstinahk pimiy ôma mîna kîhtwâm pîhtokatâwân
sentences.english: When he had used up that fat, some more was handed in to them.

sentences.original: êyôkw êh-mâstinahk, âsay nama kêkway ihtakoniyiw ôcikisiwin.
sentences.text: êwako ê-mêstinahk âsay nama kêkway ihtakoniyiw ocikisiwin
sentences.english: When he had used this up, his pock-marks were gone.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-paskît, namoya kakêtihk ta-kahkâpêwiw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-pâskît namôya kakêtihk ta-kahkâpêwiw oskinîkiw
sentences.english: And when he opened the lodge, whole and without flaw in body was the youth.

sentences.original: êkwah ka-kîwân, nôsisê, itik ôhi kâ-kîh-natawihikot;
sentences.english: “Now you will go home, my grandchild,” he was told by him who had doctored him;

sentences.original: êkwah sipwêhtêh; iskwêw anah kâ-kîh-kîhkâmisk ka-nahâpason, wîh-pêy-itohtêci kisiwâk, itik omosôma.
sentences.english: “Now depart; your sense of smell will tell you when that woman who insulted you is coming near,” his grandfather told him.
He taught him how to scold her.
Then he went home.
He came to their camp.

sentences.original: wahwâ! itwêwak ayîsiyiniwak; mistahi miyosiw oskinîkiw kâ-kîh-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.english: “Dear me!” said the people; “Very handsome is the young man who went away.”

sentences.original: êkwah aw îskwêw kâ-kîh-pakwâtât maskisinihkêsiw, ê-wîh-ntawi-miyât.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw kâ-kî-pakwâtât maskisinihkêsiw ê-wî-nitawi-miyât
sentences.english: Then the woman who had scorned him made some moccasins to give him.
When she had finished them, she went there.
Just then the youth was going out of his tent; he saw her.
The woman came to head him off.
“Here is a little present for you,” she said to him.
He took them and flung them aside.
“Oh dear, I wish I were dead,” said the woman.

sentences.original: namoya niya êkosi nôh-itwân, êh-kîhkâmiyan, itêw oskinîkiw.
sentences.english: “I did not say anything like that when you insulted me,” the youth told her.
Then the young woman went home; she was ashamed.
Of a night she would go to see him.
“A nasty smell is coming this way,” he would say whenever she came near.
She was not able to have any converse with the youth.

sentences.original: min êwakô otâcimôwiniwâw iyahciyiniwak, ê-kîh-mamâhtâwisicik kayâs ayahciyiniwak, mêkwâc paskwâwi-mostoso-wiyâs êh-mîcicik.
sentences.text: mîna êwako otâcimôwiniwâw ayahciyiniwak ê-kî-mamâhtâwisicik kayâs ayahciyiniwak mêkwâc paskwâwi-mostoso-wiyâs ê-mîcicik
sentences.english: This too is a Blackfoot story, of how the Blackfoot of old had mystic power, when they used to eat buffalo-meat.
That of which I have just finished telling is another custom of the Blackfoot.
It is wonderful that in a short time the pock-marks disappeared from his face.
So now I have finished this story.
